reviews: While I love Tumblr as a platform, their app is go glitchy 😭 it crashes and freezes often. They layout is weird, and it's a bit hard to use, especially for asks. Also I don't like Tumblr live and wish I could turn it off permanently instead of just for a week. On top of that they send me WAY too many messages! I turned off messages in the app and it didn't seem to work, so then I turned them off in settings but now they keep asking for me to turn system notifications back on 😭😭
ratings: Rated 3 stars out of five stars

reviews: I love the app, but I just have one issue with it. On the android version of it, every once and a while my activity feed will be blank. I just keep getting an error message that says "we could not complete your request at this time". This never happens when I use the IOS version of the app. And also, I don't know which update it was, but ever since then it has made images in text posts way too small. And please bring back the option to block someone who already has you blocked.
ratings: Rated 4 stars out of five stars

reviews: The app doesn't work very well for me, it freezes and lags a lot, when I agree to the update prompts, nothing seems to happen. But still - it's tumblr! Of all the "social" sites I use, this one has the largest ratio of things that make me happy as opposed to things that make me sigh in exasperation. I should add that that I have seen disturbing ads with jeffry dhomar body horror gore stuff before and I still prefer browsing on my computer for things like this.
ratings: Rated 4 stars out of five stars

reviews: Crashes about once every 2 minutes for what seems to be a variety of reasons. New update made images in text posts very very small, too small to see without making the images full-sized. You might think oh, not a problem, you can just click on the picture to make it full-sized! Nope. That crashes the app. Scrolling through posts crashes the app. Loading new posts crashes the app. Breathing near the app crashes the app.
ratings: Rated 1 stars out of five stars

reviews: The recent updates aside from polls have made this app practically unusable for me. With the new updates to the image viewer/video player you cannot zoom in on pictures or pause or rewind videos, which sucks. Additionally, the profile tab at the bottom of the screen has been swapped out for the store tab, meaning I can't easily access my profile while saving my place on the dashboard. On top of that, I hate having to snooze tumblr live every week when nobody uses it. Accessibility is tanking.
ratings: Rated 1 stars out of five stars

reviews: The new updates are terrible. The Live function is useless and can only be snoozed for a week (although it definitely comes back sooner than that). Now I click on a hard-to-read photo intending to zoom in and it won't. I swipe up to continue scrolling through the post and the rest of my dash, but instead I'm shown more random and endless posts. This is absolutely ridiculous.

reviews: 2-2-23 unremovable NEW notification on Live feature. I'd also like to see the archive of each blog, something that's easy to find on desktop.

And forget about being able to scrub through videos, zoom in on photos, or even SEE smaller images, because the ALT text box completely covers them up now. Lastly, I don't wanna "snooze" tumblr live- I want it off my dash permanently.

You cannot swipe out of the image to go back to dash; it just shows images from different posts! Also it displays your primary blog instead of the sideblog it was posted from; for people who have separate private & public/business blogs, that's a huge privacy concern! This all is atrocious and unnecessary.

Also, I don't want to be able to scroll to other videos or pictures from the post I'm on. That's content from people I don't follow and have zero control over choosing to see. Between that and Tumblr live, I'm not sure I like this app's direction. I understand they need money, but not a fan.

reviews: Tumblr Live is a security nightmare run by a third party with separate privacy practices, and Tumblr won't let you permanently turn it off, only snooze it for 7 days. It's a terrible sign about Tumblr's ethics and priorities bundled with a feature nobody asked for, and points toward dark days for Tumblr's future for those that supported it as ethical socmed.

ratings: Rated 2 stars out of five stars

reviews: The tumblr app only survived the porn ban on my phone because I was using it to upload photos to my blog without having to transfer to the pc first. And it worked fine originally! You could make a photo post that would display nicely on both browser and app without distorting the art.  This is no longer the case. Now all image posts made by the app are text posts, with the image inserted into the text body. This causes the image to distort any time it's reblogged, as it's warped by the indents applied to the original post any time someone adds commentary. I assume the same thing is happening to video posts, as many of the videos shown on the browser are similarly distorted.  The platform itself was very good, but poor management and bad design decisions are driving it into the ground. The app is clearly no longer suitable for anything but text posts, so I will be uninstalling it and reverting to the browser until one of tumblr's fledgling competitors begins picking up steam.

reviews: Tumblr, I've been using you for years and up until now I've never thought I had any reason to complain about this app. But recently you've decided to make a change to the advertising on your app. It's really made it a much less enjoyable experience and to be honest it's put me off using it as much as I used to. I can't enjoy it when I'm scrolling down my dashboard and getting massive ads that take up most of my screen saying 'sponsored: SINGLE WOMEN IN YOUR AREA!' I have to say tumblr staff, it really cheapens the site. They're also very repetitive, with the same ads over and over again. They pop up very often along the dashboard too. Think you've gone too far with the ads this time mate. I honestly didn't mind the old ad system where they were formatted like tumblr posts, so that they weren't as disruptive. And the quality of the ads featured has definitely decreased. I don't know about anyone else's experience, but all of mine feature trashy dating site links. Not something I'd expect from tumblr. Anyway, it'd be great if you reconsidered how you're using advertising on this app. If it stays like this, I think I may consider not using tumblr mobile any more. Thank you.

Now, the deletions are expanding, safe mode is forced on everyone regardless of settings. And to boot, safe mode is terrible and blocks things that have nothing to do with porn. In fact, it blocks way more than it should of completely normal stuff. It is almost like the site has been coded by a paranoid nun, for lack of a better way to describe what using it feels like now. Oh yeah, and the porn bots the staff tried to delete are back. And, the Tumblr algorithm keeps recommending them to me... Giod job Tumblr staff, you have successfully inspired me to move back to Twitter.

reviews: All my friends have left since the content ban. One of my sideblogs has been hidden altogether. The damn app was so clunky and hard to use in the first place that the content was all that kept me coming back and now everyone's walking on eggshells becayse everyone knows none of their content , adult or not, is safe.   Tumblr was already declining in popularity and this is just the final nail in the coffin. The app and the site are quickly becoming a ghost town, going the way of GeoCities and MySpace as an odd internet relic.   If nothing else, for better or worse, Tumblr used to be a place people felt safe being themselves. Now that's gone. Maybe if the ban were reversed, maybe if some of the mod developers were brought onto the team, maybe if the users were treated with a little trust or respect, the site could be salvaged, but at this stage I seriously doubt it.

reviews: Tumblr claims to be a place that encourages you to be yourself, share what you like, bond with others that share your interests. Yet, it's choosing to outright ban NSFW media (excluding written erotica, so not even properly across the board), of which people absolutely use to express themselves. This year, they have made it so 'explicit' pages cannot be viewed without a login, forced the new 'safe mode' as a default to every single user's settings, and removed explicit blogs from showing up in tags altogether. The toggle-able ability to hide mature content was more than enough. Removing this means of expression not only isolates those who once felt safe and comfortable sharing these interests, but it also greatly hurts adult artists and sex workers who were making a living in this interactive community. Yet, no work has been put into clearing the site of all the terrible harassment and hate speech that the ToS also clearly claims to be against. (also, the app is terrible. There are many aspects of it that are all around more accessible on the web version, not to mention users' blogs not showing properly, search functions completely breaking, and all the menus you have to go through just to access your inbox. Priorities are obviously misplaced all around)

Expect a large scale user Exodus and a flagging community left behind.

reviews: Tumblr, both for me and my friends, used to be a space where we can share our art and talk about what we're interested in. I met some of my good friends, my favored artistic inspirations, and much more with this site. But as of now, it has become an even more hollow shell of what it used to be. Not only is it not taking care of its primary issues of rampant child pornography and hate groups, and let useless bots arbitrarily hide posts they suspects to possess inappropriate nudity (i.e.: "female presenting nipples"), but Tumblr does NOT allow for an appeal for the hidden posts to shown again-the Tumblr bots completely change its targeted posts to be completely inaccessible with no visible option on the edited post to contact the Tumblr staff to change it.   Tumblr is censoring its own users.  So unless you want to take exhaustive shortcuts to evade this application's obsolete bot system, deal with pedophiles and white nationalists alike spewing their individual propagandas, and witness both your own and your friends' most prized art pieces become hidden from the public for good, I suggest NOT to waste your time with this app, today or even in the future.

reviews: I'm not really impressed with their new guidelines banning nudity. Sure, some images are blatant pornography (not that I have a problem with it). I think the bigger issue is that while there will be no more issues concerning "NSFW" images and pages, Tumblr will become NSFE (Not Safe For Expression). There are plenty of photographs/images from artists that actually celebrate the human form. These types of works are an important part in helping to promote acceptance of one's body and taboos concerning nudity. I just think it's quite a shame that Tumblr will end up cutting off the good in order to be safe from the "bad." It really does take away the artistic freedom of the artist and their voice. Not to mention the amount of reach they have with sharing their work with others. Ultimately it puts a damper on their very livelihood. It think it's the wrong decision and it's sad to see.

reviews: This app has serious glitches in preformance. The staff has a huge problem with understanding coding. Yet instead of fixing these errors, listening to it's users when the virus bots began pushing unwanted porn past censors, or having a dedicated team to a decent reporting system they've implemented the most useless features and only worried about the porn problems when they were called out by higher powers. There is STILL a rampant pornbot issue because tumblr has a faulty bot flagging and is removing anything but the actual problem content. So if you're looking for an app that will crash constantly, add features you don't want or need, ignore functionality and workability, deem your photo of a dinosaur as inapropriate but completely ignore the pornbots, and then effectively do nothing when you report users for harrassment then this is the app for you.

reviews: The app is and has always been terrible, but until now I've put up with it because I liked the website. Yahoo bought it a couple years ago, apparently realized that tumblr is basically impossible to market to, and have been sabotaging the website ever since. The most recent development is the ban of "adult content", which is stupid on multiple levels. Mostly because it's a website for adults. But also this is literally fixing 0 of the major problems currently plaguing the site, such as literal real life white supremacists, death/doxing threats and other forms of hate mail, hate speech in general really, and a LOT of child porn. The last one they finally addressed when the FBI got involved but not a moment before. The only thing this comes even close to fixing is the porn bots, (which are EVERYWHERE) and that isn't even fixed by this ban since they will just take their content off tumblr but spam the site with links. To make things worse the algorithm they have set up blocks any image with any sort of warm skin tone, instead of just filtering out literal actual porn. It used to be a really cool platform, it felt like the internet used to before your name was attached to everything. It was a platform that allowed people to express themselves creatively and talk about their interests without having to worry about your taste in memes being exposed to the whole world. Too bad Yahoo/tumblr values their advertisers more than their users. Soon they will have neither. If you are looking for new social media to join, look somewhere else. I've been using this site for almost 10 years now, but I can promise you it's only going to get worse from here.

reviews: It was useful at one point, given that it had a decent user base of both wholesome and risque artists. Then, of course, Tumblr decided to encroach on the artists freedom of expression by disallowing NSFW content. Couldn't have any "female presenting nipples" on their site, now could they? Unfortunately, Tumblr decided it wanted not just to throw itself of a cliff, but to tumble whilst tazing itself the whole way down: they use an algorithm. Algorithms have this funny quirk of being good in every other context, apart from governing elements of social media. This is because an algorithm has trouble distinguishing between a picture of a sexual act and a picture of Danny DeVito. So everyone is hindered by this change. This platform shouldn't be disregarded in its entirety, however. I am quite find of how, at least on mobile, you can continue scrolling through your timeline for as long as you like. It's an important feature that all other social media platforms should embrace. Don't embrace the rest of Tumblr, though.

reviews: I've had Tumblr since I was 11. Tumblr has been a part of my life for nearly a decade, and has taught me so accept my sexuality, given me friends I may have never met outside of it, and allowed me to express myself. However, in the recent years, the app and website have become a joke amongst users, as the staff never seems to listen to the real requests of actual users. This most recent change to it's policy regarding adult posts is what will make Tumblr fall apart once and for all. For this reason, I gave the app one star and this review. Maybe if you listened to your users instead of looking for a quick fix, things would have been okay. Instead, now, you're CANCELLED. And it's all on you, Tumblr Staff. To the other users that grew up with Tumblr: It's been a wild ride, friends. Let's hope things change!

reviews: Tumblr's newest attempt at making their app family friendly is entirely overdone. They have done away with the "safe search" filter option all together, opting instead for complete censorship across it's entire user base.They completely deleted entire tags; including tags that are not directly related to adult content. Many of these being tags that include fashion or aesthetic related content. While I understand and agree with the need for a way to make the app safe for minors and other users who would rather not see adult content, it should be an optional feature rather than an enforced rule (assuming said content is legal). Many small adult content creators rely on Tumblr's platform as a source of income. Because of this change in policy their blogs, content, and, in a way, their livelihoods are being deleted. All of this could be easily fixed if, in addition to the efforts to flag adult content, it was merely rendered optional instead of being completely deleted. A simple switch in the account settings with the default being set to "off" should be sufficient for keeping the app we all know and love/hate safe.

reviews: Tumblr is an app for people of all kinds with interests of all kinds. We have users of every age, race, gender, political group, sexuality, and any other category of human you could think of. Many of us consider this site a safe haven to express ourselves amongst others that don't know us. Many of us have multiple blogs for focused on different interests. We use each one to interact with others who have similar interests. It's a place unlike facebook, instagram, or twitter where we can truly share our most personal passions without the judgement of others. Tumblr has recently announced that they plan on taking this away from us on Dec.17th. I understand wanting to make this a website for everyone, and I have a suspicion that they only brought this up now because of the increase in sexual spam bots as of late, but that does not give them the right to take away the freedom of half of this sites actual users. Instead of dealing with these bots themselves tumblr staff has created a content sifter that will simply remove any content that seems to have a skintone. So not only is sexual content being removed, any photo with a certain color tone will be removed. We've seen this first hand in what has been flagged as "explicit content" so far. A picture of someone's arm has been flagged. A picture of a baby has been flagged. Completely unsexualized art has been flagged. A screencap of thor from the actual marvel movie was flagged. A screencap of mario from the actual mario odyssey game was flagged. A stock photo of a man fully clothed playing video games was flagged. A screencap of Kirby from the actual smash bros game was flagged. A photo of a package of wonder bread was flagged. I don't think I need to go on to prove the point that there is clearly a monumental issue with this system of "problem solving". Doing away with half of a site's user base as a solution to too many pornography bots is not a solution at all. The attitude that the tumblr staff has presented us with regarding this problem is not only irresponsible but downright lazy. I'm more than dissapointed in the lack of attentiveness the tumblr staff has has shown towards real issues on this site. This whole sensorship ordeal is not the only issue that this site has been experiencing lately though so I'll move on. As of late none of my links to tumblr posts sent via text have worked. All have failed to open properly for the reciever, who also has the tumblr app. We decided to experiment with sending posts by other means and none were completely successful, not even sending them through tumblr's own messaging system. I enjoy sharing funny or informative posts with my friends like anyone on any social media platform does, so this issue has been particularly annoying for me. There's more than a few other issues that come to mind but they're bugs that have been present in tumblr mobile since the dawn of time, so I don't feel the need to mention them nor do I have hope that they will ever be taken care of. All in all tumblr as a community is fantastic, but those who run it have shown an abysmal amount of care for their user base. I truly hope this changes soon.

reviews: Tumblr is banning adult content after failing miserably to control it. This includes a ton of expressive art, 18+ blogs for humor/fun, and, of course, one of the many reasons people use this app. It helped propagate and proliferate new kinks to all, wonderful bedroom ideas, and gave a meaningful place to find content that wasn't systematically categorized. It made such content feel less degrading and more humanizing through this lack of categorization, and yet still allowed many to browse and share content they enjoyed. It made this content feel less awful to view and, oddly, wholesome in that it presented it in a more human form. It was a wonderful niche for that, and now they are ruining it for everyone because of a failure to better market themselves.

The way you are handling the problems that tumblr faces will not see that happen before it fizzles out and dies. The only thing that appears with  any speed is of course, Advertisements, Which leads  in to the other reasons for my low score.  It's clear that the Staff and current company behind Tumblr  only care for the revenue they get through adds and traffic, regardless of where that traffic comes from.  Bots that take  over posts and  inject their malicious links are and have been frequent  problem that the community has even  tried to mass-report more then once. These bots will  follow anyone, message you and  persist even after the purge and guideline adjustment  These bots are  90% ronograpthic in nature,  even Childporn.  But nothing  aside from a bungled, ill-thought out guideline change and  neural network where  put in place.  Punishing the  user base  While white nationalists and other hatespeech- runs wild and  unpunished  with the pornbots.

reviews: What was once a vibrant site that had wide variety of content from all sorts of creators, is now a shell of its former self. Ever since the nsfw ban, a lot of the artists, activists, and sex workers i followed have been force to scatter across different sites. Many have lost, or had their livelihood significantly damaged because tumblr used to be The Place for them to share their work and ideas. Tumblr could've had a neopets-esque system that automatically blocked users under 18 from seeing certain content/blogs, and of course safe mode (and the blacklist providing by xkit) do wonders for keeping unwanted content out of sight. They could've just worked with those features to make the site safer, but instead they shot themselves in the foot and started bleeding out hundreds of users who made the site worthwhile. Tumblr wont die overnight. It probably wont even be dead by the end of 2019. But it has already started on its slow death march and the only reason im sad is because of the communities we've lost.

reviews: Been a user since 2014 and have somehow made it through the ups and downs thus far. Now I am incredibly disappointed with this app's performance and the staff's failure to fix many of its issues and have only made more ridiculous mistakes. Many errors when loading a search in the past would appear and videos would either be unplayable or crash the app. If my android was low on battery and I was watching a video, there was no easy way to close out the video. Many posts don't get viewed and the "most recent" and "top" wouldn't work sometimes. The gif tag never worked when I tried it and every time I was hopeful it would someday, I was always let down. And now with the extreme and pathetic "solution" the staff have come up with for their child pornography problem (which I am glad that they finally have become aware of that), they purged all nsfw content and any potentially nsfw tag has been blocked. Is this a joke? This app is rated 17+ and I, as a legal adult of 19 should be allowed to view the nsfw content. Safe search was an option for anyone who was not interested and blacklisting certain tags was also available, which I appreciated and made sure to use. Now many blogs that had nothing to do with the problem have been removed while phishing porn bots continue at large. Censoring legal content accomplishes nothing except losing many users. I am only considering staying for friends that have been lucky not to be purged and although I have lost any hope for tumblr at this point, maybe the staff will listen to its users after seeing their ratings take a dive.

reviews: I've been using tumblr for about 7 years now, and the vast majority of that time has been from the app. Using it has ranged from frustrating to unusable. Staff has never been transparent in communications and only 1/5 of updates are actually helpful and needed. The blocking system doesn't work and hasn't for years, the tagging system is still broken after staff broke it, the trending page is controlled by staff and has been for years to keep political things off and now with their most recent change it seems staff is trying to see how quickly they can destroy their own platform. I dont think I'll continue to use tumblr after the 17th. This isnt just about the nsfw ban but the buildup leading to this. The taking down of BLM and Ferguson from trending tags, the unfair treatment of LGBT people by the censors, the horrific coding of the app, the astounding number of bugs in the app, and now with them burning half the site down to kill a spider, I dont think I can stay. I will list the changes I did like. Adding an official way to blacklist tags, messaging, the trending page in theory is fine, i like the 'most popular posts' at the top of blogs, and the app did get more stable as time went on. But these are small fixes. Repainting the door wont help if half the house is still in ashes. The app gets one star until they can fix the problems users have been complaining about for years that staff has ignored

reviews: Tumblr used to be my fav app, not only for traditional nsfw content but also for art that includes mature themes. The recent decision by tumblr executives has left me saddened, Tumblr is a place of free expression of the human experience and a large part of that experience is erotic in nature. To blindly assume that removing this vital part of the app will somehow make it better is shortsighted and naive. I love Tumblr and i don't want to leave it but if this decision isn't reversed then i will be left with no other choice. My word of advice to you tumblr is to listen to your users and make the decision that benefits all of us, even a compromise would be better than this all or nothing philosophy. I suggest finding a better solution such as a toggle for users that don't want to see nsfw content or "female-presenting nipples" as you so eloquently put it. I hope you think about this carefully and make the right decision. -Sincelry, a loyal and longtime user.
